ags:resource.dc:title: Effect of mergers and acquisitions on the financial performance of European food and beverage manufacturing firms [Thesis (M.Sc.)]

dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Mergers and acquisitions in the corporate world continue to be a popular form of a favorable medium of growth. Consequently, the financial performance of combined companies has attracted substantial interest and research attention especially in the advent of intense globalization. Researchers have developed various approaches and methods in order to evaluate acquisition performance. The objective of this paper is to investigate the effect of merger and acquisition on the financial performance of European food and beverage manufacturing firms. The review also examines the impact of bid and company characteristics on performance. Empirical testing is limited to a sample of 48 acquisitions carried out among the European food sector which underwent mergers during the period of 2011. The enquiry was calculated by the most widely used measures of acquisition performance, namely accounting-based measures. The evidence suggests that the financial performance deteriorated within two years after an acquisition and the integration process has a significant impact on overall financial performance. Overall, the results revealed that type and category of merger, payments methods, cross-border or domestic types of deal, CEO approaches and structure of the board of directors has insignificant effects on post-merger financial performance. In contrast, relative firm size showed that it was highly significant. It is recommended that large companies are more likely to maintain a good management control after an integration event. In the light of the findings, ideas for future research are discussed and suggested.
